channel.title: WebMD Health Headlines
channel.description: WebMD Health - Trustworthy, Credible, and Timely Health Information

item.title: Therapy, Hypnosis for Irritable Bowel?
item.description: Some people may cope better with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with help from cognitive behavioral therapy and hypnosis, three new studies show.

item.title: ‘Extreme Drinking’ Common at Colleges
item.description: A new survey shows that a “surprisingly large percentage of students, particularly males, drink at peak levels well beyond the binge threshold,”

item.title: Family’s Bird Flu Deaths Stump Experts
item.description: A cluster of bird flu deaths in a family in Indonesia is getting intense scrutiny from the World Health Organization (WHO) and Indonesia’s Ministry of Health -- and it is raising concerns about human-to-human transmission of the virus.

item.title: New ED Drugs on Horizon
item.description: New treatments for erectile dysfunction are on the way. One works fast. One lasts long. And another promises to be the next best thing to a cure.

item.title: Test May Help Spot Some Breast Cancer
item.description: In some women whose genes put them at high risk of breast cancer, getting annual magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) along with mammography may be cost-effective.

item.title: Is Colonoscopy After Age 80 Worth It?
item.description: People aged 80 and older may want to talk to their doctors about whether or not they should get colonoscopies to screen for colorectal cancer.

item.title: Lab-Grown Replacement Penis in Future?
item.description: It's now possible to replace a defective, damaged, or diseased penis with a penis grown in a laboratory -- in rabbits.

item.title: Pot Smoking Not Linked to Lung Cancer
item.description: People who smoke marijuana do not appear to be at increased risk for developing lung cancer, new research suggests.

item.title: Blood Pressure Drugs Counter Cancer?
item.description: Certain cancers may be less common among people taking a type of blood pressure drug called ACE inhibitors, new studies show.

item.title: Low Vitamin D May Harm Teens’ Lungs
item.description: Teenagers who don’t get enough vitamin D in their diets may be hurting their lungs as well as their bones, according to a new study.

item.title: Money May Affect Teens' Weight Issues
item.description: Older teens living in poverty may be more likely to be overweight than their peers from wealthier families, a new study shows.

item.title: Less Sleep, More Pounds
item.description: Skimping on sleep may mean greater weight gain for women.

item.title: FDA OKs Generic Depression Drug
item.description: The FDA has approved a generic version of the antidepressant Lexapro (escitalopram oxalate).

item.title: Alcohol Won't Worsen Prostate Symptoms
item.description: If you're a drinker or an Atkins dieter, there's good news for you from this week's annual meeting of the American Urological Association in Atlanta.

item.title: PSA Screening Imperfect, but It Works
item.description: The PSA test may not be perfect, but it's a good way to screen for prostate cancer, a leading urologist says.
